<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black"> The majority of users will never have to interact with the API at all - integrations like Veeam will simply ask how long you want your files to be immutable and enable that functionality behind the scenes for you.</span></p>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black"> With Default Bucket Retention, the feature applies Object Lock for a specified retention period on files uploaded or copied into a bucket. <a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/1260804786409-Default-Bucket-Retention-Immutability-" target="_self">Read here </a><a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/1260804786409-Default-Bucket-Retention-Immutability-" target="_self">for more information</a>.</span></p>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><br><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">With Object Lock Legal Hold, the feature prevents a file from being changed or deleted, but the immutability does not have a defined retention period - a file is immutable until Object Lock Legal Hold is removed. <a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/1260804731990-Object-Lock-Legal-Hold" target="_self">Read here for more information</a>.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Does Object Lock with Backblaze work the same way as it does with AWS?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">From a functionality standpoint, Object Lock with Backblaze B2 Cloud Storage works the same way as it does with AWS. Files will be locked until the date a user sets on the file.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Is there an extra cost to use Object Lock?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">There is no extra cost to use Object Lock, however you are responsible for the normal charges associated with storing the locked file.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Can Object Lock be enabled later on?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black"><span>Yes. You may enable Object Lock on a bucket when creating a new bucket or on an existing bucket. Once enabled, the files in that bucket already and files uploaded after the enablement are eligible to be locked. Object Lock can be enabled via the Backblaze website, the S3-compatible API, the B2 Native API, the B2 SDKs, and the B2 and AWS CLIs.&nbsp;</span><br></span></p>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify">&nbsp;</p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">What happens if I made a mistake and locked a file for longer than I wanted?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">If you have locked your file for longer than you intended then you will need to close your B2 account. For assistance in closing your B2 account please see either <a href="/hc/en-us/articles/217665728" target="_self">Canceling and Deleting a Backblaze Account</a> or <a href="/hc/en-us/articles/224854887" target="_self">How Do I Cancel My B2 Account</a>.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Can I use Immutability with Veeam?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Yes, Object Lock in B2 Cloud Storage was designed with the Immutability feature in Veeam Backup &amp; Replication in mind. If you have enabled Object Lock on a bucket on your account you can follow our guide on how to set up Veeam with B2 Cloud Storage. For more information, see this <a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/1260802952870-Veeam-Cloud-Repository-Recovery-from-Backblaze-B2">page</a>.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Can I use Object Lock on a bucket that does not have it enabled?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">No, Object Lock can only be used on a bucket that has Object Lock enabled.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Can I use Object Lock with the B2 CLI/AWS CLI?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Here is an example of how to create a bucket with Object Lock enabled and upload a file to Backblaze B2 with an Object Lock, then check the retention period for that file:</span></p>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black"><strong>Creating a Bucket:</strong></span></p>
<pre><span class="wysiwyg-color-white">aws s3api create-bucket --bucket &lt;bucketname&gt; --object-lock-enabled-for-bucket --endpoint-url &lt;S3 Endpoint&gt;</span></pre>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black"><strong>Upload a File:</strong></span></p>
<pre><span class="wysiwyg-color-white">aws s3api put-object --bucket &lt;bucketname&gt; --key &lt;filename&gt; --&gt;body &lt;local_filename&gt; --object-lock-mode COMPLIANCE --object-lock-retain-until-date "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MI:SS" --endpoint-url &lt;S3 Endpoint&gt;</span></pre>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black"><strong>Check Object Retention:</strong></span></p>
<pre><span class="wysiwyg-color-white">aws s3api get-object-retention --bucket &lt;bucketname&gt; --key &lt;filename&gt; --endpoint-url &lt;S3 Endpoint&gt;</span></pre>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Can I only use Object Lock with the S3 Compatibility API?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">No, Object Lock is available via the S3 Compatibility API and the B2 Native API.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">What happens after the end of the retention period?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Once the Object Lock retention period expires, a file may be changed or deleted.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Will Object Lock affect any other bucket or lifecycle settings?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Yes. When a file is locked, lifecycle settings or an integration setting attempting to change or delete the file will fail.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Can Object Lock only be enabled using the WEB UI? If not how can it be otherwise enabled?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Object Lock may be enabled by API or by using the web application. See this <a href="https://www.backblaze.com/b2/docs/file_lock.html">page</a> for more information about our API. <a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/1260804786409-Default-Bucket-Retention-Immutability-" target="_self">Default Bucket Retention </a>and <a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/1260804731990-Object-Lock-Legal-Hold" target="_self">Object Lock Legal Hold </a>may be enabled through the web application as well.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Can Object Lock Legal Hold be enabled for multiple files at once?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">No, Object Lock Legal Hold may be applied only one file at a time during upload or updating a file.</span></p>
<h2 class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">What are examples of who or what Default Bucket Retention would usually apply to?</span></h2>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-justify"><span class="wysiwyg-color-black">Default Bucket Retention is a great feature for those who want to ensure that their data is not changed or deleted. Refer to the <a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/1260804786409-Default-Bucket-Retention-Immutability-" target="_self">Default Bucket Retention article </a>for more information.</span></p>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <a href="/hc/en-us/articles/360052973274-Object-Lock-FAQs" class="btn btn--primary promoted__body-btn">
                                    <span>Read more</span>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-right is-hidden--rtl"></i>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-left is-hidden--ltr"></i>
                                </a>
                            </div>
                        
                            <div id="promoted-360010017893" class="tabs__container" aria-hidden="true">
                                <div class="promoted__body-container">
                                    <h2>Delivering Private Backblaze B2 Content Through Cloudflare CDN</h2>
                                    <div data-article-body="" data-plugin-article-body="">
                                        <p>This article explains how to use Cloudflare Workers to serve data from a <em>private</em> B2 Bucket. If you would like to allow Cloudflare to fetch content from a <em>public</em> Backblaze B2 Bucket, see the <a href="https://help.backblaze.com/hc/en-us/articles/13560118643099" target="_self" rel="undefined">KB article on using Cloudflare Workers to fetch content from a public B2 Bucket</a>.</p>
<h1>Introduction</h1>
<p>Many customers have expressed interest in hosting static data for their website (ranging from minified Javascript applications to multi-hour 8K video) because of the security, reliability, and affordability of Backblaze B2 storage. One solution to ensuring performance and availability is to route requests through a CDN (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_delivery_network" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>C</strong>ontent <strong>D</strong>elivery <strong>N</strong>etwork</a>) such as Backblaze's Bandwidth Alliance partner Cloudflare, taking advantage of Cloudflare's performance and the free data transfer between Backblaze B2 and Cloudflare.</p>
<h2>How does a CDN like Cloudflare work?</h2>
<p>Cloudflare leverages DNS (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_Name_System" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>D</strong>omain<strong> N</strong>ame<strong> S</strong>ystem</a>) so that content requests come to Cloudflare's servers. Through caching and private high-speed links, Cloudflare ensures high availability and reliability from storage. A website's domain name is registered with Cloudflare (and transferred from its domain name registrar), so that Cloudflare becomes responsible for serving content from that domain. Behind the scenes, Cloudflare allows a website's domain to be aliased to some other domain, so that a user may see images and content from <a href="https://www.coffeemaniacs.com">https://www.coffeemaniacs.com</a>&nbsp;when those images and that content is actually being served from Backblaze B2 (<a href="https://f345.backblazeb2.com/file/coffemaniacs">https://f345.backblazeb2.com/file/coffemaniacs-storage)</a></p>
<h2>Backblaze Buckets are on the Internet Securely</h2>
<p>Although all buckets are addressable from the internet, only public buckets can be accessed by just anybody. By default, Backblaze B2 storage is private, which means that access requires authentication. Backblaze's various integration partners have incorporated this security into their tools to keep Backblaze B2 as user-friendly as possible while still maintaining security.</p>
<h2>Website Content from Secure Buckets</h2>
<p>Putting these elements together means that customers serving data from their website want to serve from their website; they want to store their photos and videos and all of their digital content in a private bucket, available through (and only through) their website. When hosting a website directly, adding the authentication required to pull data from Backblaze B2 is straightforward. Fronting a website through Cloudflare is slightly more complex: now Cloudflare has to access private buckets to retrieve and cache data, which means Cloudflare has to authenticate its requests to Backblaze B2.</p>
<h2>Web Workers for the Win</h2>
<p>Cloudflare offers <a href="https://www.cloudflare.com/products/cloudflare-workers/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">web workers</a>, small Javascript snippets that allow rewriting HTTP and HTTPS requests on the fly. These make it straightforward to add authentication headers to content requests, and authenticate the link between Cloudflare and Backblaze B2. Even better, Cloudflare's web workers can be uploaded directly into Cloudflare's servers making the automation of the process straightforward. Web workers are available at all plan levels (including the free plan), for a nominal charge (please see Cloudflare's site for their pricing and plan). At the free level, only one script is possible, but one is enough to allow Cloudflare access to otherwise private data.</p>
<h2>Web Workers, Updates, and Authorizations: Working Together</h2>
<p>One solution is to use a Web Worker to rewrite the request URLs on the fly, adding an <strong>Authorization</strong> parameter. Although an authorization is good for any number of requests, B2 authorizations eventually expire (the longest period of time an authorization can persist is 7 days). Manually updating the authorization each week would be a chore: this is something that should happen automatically. Fortunately, both Backblaze B2 and Cloudflare offer APIs that can automate the process. The procedure here uses a Python script and the B2 APIs to get a new B2 download authorization, good for 7 days from the moment the script runs. After embedding that authorization into a Javascript snippet, the Python script uses the Cloudflare APIs to upload the script. By using a scheduler such as&nbsp;<em>cron</em> on Linux or MacOS, or&nbsp;<em>schtasks</em> on Windows, an administrator can automate running the script every day or two, thus ensuring the authorization code is always current. This article contains the complete script, as well as instructions on modifying it with the right parameters.</p>
<h2>Setting up to enable access to your private bucket</h2>
<p>Building this connection requires:</p>
<ul>
<li>A Backblaze account</li>
<li>An ApplicationKey and ApplicationKeyID that gives read access to the private bucket</li>
<li>The name of the Backblaze B2 file server for the bucket</li>
<li>A Cloudflare account</li>
<li>A top-level internet domain (such as <a href="http://www.pawneeparks.org">www.pawneeparks.org</a>)</li>
<li>Cloudflare Web Worker access</li>
<li>The Cloudflare API key</li>
<li>The Cloudflare Zone ID</li>
<li>A Python3 program to get a refreshed authorization token and upload it to Cloudflare along with the worker code (available at <a href="https://github.com/Backblaze/gists/blob/master/b2AuthorizeCfWorker.py">Github</a>). (Once <a href="https://blog.cloudflare.com/introducing-workers-kv/">Cloudflare's recently announced Workers KV</a> comes out of beta, we will update this article to store the authorization key in this distributed database.)</li>
<li>A server running cron (or something similar) to run the python3 update at regular intervals</li>
</ul>
<h1>Guide</h1>
<h2>Gather the information needed about your Backblaze B2 account</h2>
<p>If you do not already have a Backblaze account, <a href="https://www.backblaze.com/b2/sign-up.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sign up for one here</a>. Backblaze B2 includes 10 gigabytes of free storage and does not require a billing method to get started exploring the possibilities.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308056731/B2signup1.png" alt="B2signup1.png"></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>After creating (or signing into) your Backblaze B2 account, go to <strong>My Account</strong> on the top menu, and then select&nbsp;<strong>Buckets</strong> in the right hand menu</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-center"><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308079771/cloudflare1.png" alt="cloudflare1.png" width="645" height="468"></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>This will open the bucket UI screen, and if this is a new account, it will have no buckets (yet).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="wysiwyg-text-align-center"><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403314758555/cloudflare2.png" alt="cloudflare2.png" width="645" height="640"></p>
<p>Redirecting traffic requires having a bucket. Clicking on 'Create Bucket' brings up the bucket creation dialog.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308210587/cloudflare3.png" alt="cloudflare3.png"></p>
<p>Choose a name (not the one in the dialog). Bucket names must be globally unique across all Backblaze B2 accounts. Choosing a name already in use will return an error; should this happen, simply choose another name. Users of the redirected content will not see this name.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308228635/cloudflare4.png" alt="cloudflare4.png"></p>
<p>As long as we are here, get the BucketId for this bucket (this is a globally unique identifier). Next, upload a file (it does not matter what). Click on Upload/Download.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308246939/cloudflare5.png" alt="cloudflare5.png"></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Click on upload, and send a text or HTML file up to Backblaze B2 (we will retrieve it as part of testing the integration) later. This file will be referred to later as <em>uploadedFile.html</em>.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308287515/cloudflare6.png" alt="cloudflare6.png"></p>
<p>Just drag and drop a file, and upload it to the Backblaze B2 bucket.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308397595/cloudflare7.png" alt="cloudflare7.png"></p>
<p>Find the white i in a small gray circle at the far right of the file listing (circled in green), and click on that. It gives information about the file: we are looking for the fileserver for this account (all buckets from this account will utilize this particular fileserver).</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308413467/cloudflare8.png" alt="cloudflare8.png"></p>
<p>As shown, the fileserver for this bucket is&nbsp;<a href="https://f001.backblazeb2.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://f001.backblazeb2.com</a>. Make a note of the fileserver, as this is the top-level domain that is the target of the remap. Also note that the filepath is &lt;<em>fileserver</em>&gt;<strong>/file/</strong>&lt;<em>BucketName</em>&gt;/filename&nbsp;— this pattern is used to source content through the remapped domain (more detail on this later).</p>
<p>Next, get (or create) an applicationKeyId and applicationKey to generate authorization tokens. Once the file information dialog is dismissed, click on the 'Buckets' menu item in the left-hand menu to return to the main Buckets page. Near the top of the page, is a link to Show Account Key and Application Key.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308475291/cloudflare9.png" alt="cloudflare9.png"></p>
<p>Click on this link to go to the key management.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403314910619/cloudflare10.png" alt="cloudflare10.png"></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Although it is possible to use the Master Application Key ID and Master Application Key, it is preferable to use a key with less access. Scrolling down this screen a bit gives:</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403308495643/cloudflare11.png" alt="cloudflare11.png"></p>
<p>This will create an ApplicationKeyID and ApplicationKey (and this one is scoped to provide full read and write access to the bucket).&nbsp;<strong>Please note that the ApplicationKey is displayed exactly once. Although another key can be created with similar permissions, this particular key cannot be regenerated. This key gives access to your bucket, and should be kept securely.&nbsp;</strong>Application keys enable a great deal of flexibility in granting access to your stored content.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/4403314967067/cloudflare12.png" alt="cloudflare12.png"></p>
<p>Note the ApplicationKey (<strong>again: this is the only time it will be displayed</strong>) and the ApplicationKeyId for the bucket. The ApplicationKeyId, along with the KeyName, are listed (as are all keys created for an account).</p>
<p>This is all the information required from Backblaze.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Set up the Cloudflare account</h2>
<p>If you do not already have a Cloudflare account, sign up for one at <a href="https://www.cloudflare.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloudflare</a>.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360013915714/Screenshot_2018-10-01_16.01.33.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-01_16.01.33.png"></p>
<p>and sign up:</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360013915934/Screen_Shot_2018-10-01_at_4.07.09_PM.png" alt="Screen_Shot_2018-10-01_at_4.07.09_PM.png"></p>
<p>After signing up, register your top-level domain with Cloudflare by going to 'add record'.&nbsp; Ensure the record type is CNAME. This will map your top level domain (here&nbsp;<em>static.pawneeparks.org</em>) to the source that Cloudflare will fetch content from.</p>
<p>Click on 'add record', and then make sure the cloud icon directly to the right of the 'Automatic TTL' choice box and directly to the left of the 'Add Record' button is orange; if it is gray, click it once to change the setting from 'DNS only' to 'DNS and HTTP Proxy'.</p>
<p>The next step requires adding billing information, and a subscription to web workers. After this is accomplished, go the the workers page, and launch the editor.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014064174/Screenshot_2018-10-02_14.44.26.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_14.44.26.png">Do not modify the default script (there is no need).&nbsp;<strong>However, the script must be saved by clicking the 'save' button&nbsp;</strong>(circled in green). Clicking this button may not appear to do anything, but it is absolutely required for the next step, which is to specify the route on which the worker script is enabled.<img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014064774/Screenshot_2018-10-02_14.53.20.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_14.53.20.png"></p>
<p>Click on the 'routes' tab (circled in green) to show the routes.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014064874/Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.04.43.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.04.43.png">&nbsp;click 'Add Route' to add a route, and it should show up.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014109073/Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.31.31.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.31.31.png"></p>
<p>and the script will show as enabled for this script:</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014066334/Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.21.33.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.21.33.png"></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>The routing is set up, and the script will be taken care of automatically by python script, but we will need an API key for Cloudflare. Click on 'Dashboard' to return to the main Cloudflare interface, and then go to the Overview.<img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014109593/Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.44.05.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.44.05.png"></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Several things require attention here. First, SSL should be set to&nbsp;<strong>Full (Strict)</strong> to ensure that Cloudflare verifies certificates from Backblaze B2 storage. Next, the&nbsp;<strong>Zone ID</strong> is required to upload our worker script, as is the API key. After noting the Zone ID, click on 'Get your API key'.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014109653/Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.55.21.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_15.55.21.png"></p>
<p>and scroll down to the bottom of this page. The final section is&nbsp;<strong>API Keys</strong>. The required information is the global API key. Click&nbsp;<strong>View&nbsp;</strong>to display the API key, and make note of it. Cloudflare will require account verification.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014066734/Screenshot_2018-10-02_16.00.58.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_16.00.58.png"></p>
<p>It will reveal your API key:</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360014109933/Screenshot_2018-10-02_16.01.58.png" alt="Screenshot_2018-10-02_16.01.58.png"></p>
<p><strong>Please note: under no circumstances display your API key in a public forum.</strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Setting up the authorized web worker with Cron</h2>
<p>Since Backblaze B2 authorization tokens expire, feeding a CDN requires updating the authorization token. The simplest way to do this is to replace the entire worker script with a new one, where the authorization token is hard-coded into the Javascript. To make this easier, here is a script which, given the identities, identifiers, and keys, will get a new authorization token from Backblaze, embed it into a web worker script that will add the token as a header to incoming requests, and then upload the script to Cloudflare. By default, the script's authorization tokens are valid for one week (the maximum possible time). If this script is scheduled to run once a day, then the script can be missed for five days before the authorization token expires.</p>
<p>Setting up a Python script to run at regular intervals is beyond the scope of this guide, as is setting up a Python3 environment. <a href="https://github.com/Backblaze/gists/blob/master/b2AuthorizeCfWorker.py">This is the Python3 script to get a B2 authorization token and upload a web worker to authorize Cloudflare requests to the private bucket is available.</a></p>
<p>This script requires some customization, as a number of values are specific to the user.</p>
<dl>
<dt><tt>cloudflareEmail</tt></dt>
<dd>The email address registered as the account owner in Cloudflare</dd>
<dt><tt>bucketSourceId</tt></dt>
<dd>The hexadecimal bucket identifer for the source bucket in Backblaze B2</dd>
<dt><tt>bucketFilenamePrefix</tt></dt>
<dd>The filename prefix (if any) for which the B2 ApplicationKey is valid</dd>
<dt><tt>cfZoneId</tt></dt>
<dd>The Zone ID for the Cloudflare account</dd>
<dt><tt>b2AppKey</tt></dt>
<dd>This is the Backblaze B2 Application Key to authorize access to the Backblaze B2 bucket. <em>This is the secret key that is displayed exactly one time and never again.</em></dd>
<dt><tt>b2AppKeyId</tt></dt>
<dd>This is the Backblaze B2 Application Key ID. It is also a long string, but it is displayed in the list of existing keys.</dd>
<dt><tt>maxSecondsAuthValid</tt></dt>
<dd>The number of seconds for which the authorization is valid when created. The default script value is a week, which is the maximum time-to-live of any authorization token. The valid time may be set to a smaller value. However, this should be weighed against how often the <tt>cron</tt> job will run. If the <tt>cron</tt> job runs once a day, then if it is skipped for a day or two or even five, the authorization remains active if the authorization token lasts for a week.</dd>
</dl>
<hr>
<p>
<script src="https://gist-it.appspot.com/github/Backblaze/gists/blob/master/b2AuthorizeCfWorker.py"></script>
</p>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <a href="/hc/en-us/articles/360010017893-Delivering-Private-Backblaze-B2-Content-Through-Cloudflare-CDN" class="btn btn--primary promoted__body-btn">
                                    <span>Read more</span>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-right is-hidden--rtl"></i>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-left is-hidden--ltr"></i>
                                </a>
                            </div>
                        
                            <div id="promoted-360002004214" class="tabs__container" aria-hidden="true">
                                <div class="promoted__body-container">
                                    <h2>How to Upload Files to B2 Using Fireball</h2>
                                    <div data-article-body="" data-plugin-article-body="">
                                        <!--?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?-->
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Backblaze Fireball program consists of a Synology NAS with 10GigE add-in card, and hard drives shipped to the customer.</span> The customer sets up the NAS, moves the data to it, and after configuring and testing the configuration for validity, returns the NAS to Backblaze. When Backblaze receives the NAS, the data is moved to B2 storage, verified, and then the data is cleared from the NAS.</p>
<hr>
<div style="margin: 1em 0em 2em 0em;">
<div style="border: 5px; border-style: solid; border-color: darkcyan; padding: 10px; margin: 0 5% 0 5%; background-color: azure;">
<h3 style="text-align: center; color: navy; font-variant: small-caps;"><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-x-large">Please Take Note:</span></h3>
<ul>
<li><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-large wysiwyg-color-blue130">Seeding data for use with a third-party backup or archiving tool may require additional steps or preparation.<br></span>
<ul>
<li><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-large wysiwyg-color-blue130">In many cases, the data must be loaded onto the Fireball with the integration partner’s tools.<br></span></li>
<li><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-large wysiwyg-color-blue130">Some software may have additional requirements. Please check with our integration partner if there is any uncertainty.</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-large wysiwyg-color-blue130">Please note <a href="#copyData">the filename restrictions when copying data</a>.</span></li>
</ul>
</div>
<br>
<h2>Quick Step Reference</h2>
<ol>
<li><a href="#unpackSetup">Unpack and set up the Synology NAS</a></li>
<li><a href="#connectNetwork">Connect the NAS to the network</a></li>
<li><a href="#installSA">Obtain Fireball password and encryption key</a></li>
<li><a href="#encryptData">Enter Fireball configuration information</a></li>
<li><a href="#winNetwork">FOR WINDOWS: Find the listing for Fireball on the local network</a></li>
<li><a href="#macNetwork">FOR MACINTOSH: Find the listing for Fireball on your local network in Finder</a></li>
<li><a href="#mountShare">Mount the share <em><tt>DataForB2</tt></em></a></li>
<li><a href="#copyData">Copy the data to the Fireball NAS</a></li>
<li><a href="#synShutDown">Return NAS settings to default, and shut down the NAS</a></li>
<li><a href="#repackDrives">Uninstall the hard drives, repack and return the Fireball to Backblaze</a></li>
<!--     
    	<li><a href="someThing">Stuff</a></li>
	--></ol>
<!--   ################################### -->
<div>
<p id="unpackSetup" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;1.</strong> Unpack and set up the Synology NAS</p>
<p>Backblaze ships the Synology NAS without the drives trays installed to better protect both NAS and drives. The disks are installed in trays, and the trays need to be placed into the NAS. The disks can be installed in any order.</p>
<p><strong>Please note: </strong>Although the illustration shows only two drive bays, all eight of the included drives must be inserted into the Synology NAS.</p>
<p><!-- orig: width="1344" height="1808" --> <img src="/hc/article_attachments/360002230214/InitialTapeInstall.png" alt="InitialTapeInstall.png" width="672" height="904"></p>
<!-- -->
<p id="connectNetwork" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;2.</strong> Connect the NAS to the network</p>
<p>The Fireball NAS must be connected directly to the network. At a small office, this might be a network switch or router. For best results, use a wired connection via ethernet cable.&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">The NAS cannot be directly connected to a computer. The NAS supports only a direct network connection via either the 1GigE or 10GigE ports.</span></li>
<li>The NAS should be connected to the data source over a wired connection. Wireless (Wi-Fi) connections have limited bandwidth, and data transfer will take much longer than with a direct connection. Also, network traffic to other devices on the wireless network can suffer performance loss when competing for bandwidth with the NAS.</li>
<li>Connect the power cable to the NAS, plug the NAS in, and then turn it on with the power button.</li>
</ul>
<!-- -->
<p id="installSA" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;3.</strong> Get your Fireball's password and encryption key</p>
<ul>
<li>The username for all Fireballs is always “<tt>backblaze</tt>”. To obtain this particular Fireball’s password and encryption key:
<ul>
<li><a href="https://secure.backblaze.com/user_signin.htm?" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sign into the B2 account to which the data is to be transferred.</a></li>
<li>Navigate to <em>Fireball.</em></li>
<li>Click the blue ‘<tt><em>i</em></tt>’ icon associated with this Fireball order.<br><br><img src="/hc/article_attachments/6046703838235/mceclip0.png" alt="mceclip0.png"></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<!-- -->
<p id="encryptData" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;4.</strong> Enter your Fireball's password and encryption key on your Fireball</p>
<p>To protect customer data, all data sent to Backblaze on the NAS is encrypted.</p>
<ol>
<li>Visit <a href="http://find.synology.com/" target="_self">find.synology.com</a> to scan your local network for all Synology devices.<br>
<ul>
<li>Double click the Fireball in the list, and your browser should connect directly to the Fireball's web page</li>
<li>If no Fireballs are detected, double check your network connection with the Fireball, ensuring it's on the same subnet as your computer</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Log in using 'backblaze' as the username and the password you obtained from your B2 account</li>
<li>In the browser window, navigate to <strong>‘Control Panel’</strong></li>
<li>Navigate to <strong>‘Shared Folder’</strong></li>
<li>Click once on <strong>‘DataForB2’</strong>to select it</li>
<li>Click on <strong>‘Encryption’</strong></li>
<li>Choose <strong>‘Mount’</strong></li>
<li>Enter the encryption key you obtained from your B2 account to mount the encrypted Shared Folder.</li>
<li>This concludes the browser configuration of the Fireball, so you can close the window</li>
</ol>
<p><strong><em>Please Note:</em> The encryption key is kept only in volatile storage (in memory) on the Fireball.</strong> Every time the NAS is powered down or reset, this configuration information (the encryption key) must be re-entered.</p>
<p><!-- width="1387" height="632" --> <!-- cut by 1/3: width="462" height="211" --> <img src="/hc/article_attachments/360002229773/SynologyMountScreen.png" alt="SynologyMountScreen.png" width="462" height="211"></p>
<!-- -->
<p id="winNetwork" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;5.</strong> FOR WINDOWS: Find the listing for Fireball on the local network</p>
<p>The Fireball should be in the network listing.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360002230134/WinNetworkListing.png" alt="WinNetworkListing.png"></p>
<p>If the device is missing from this list, open Windows Explorer and type “<tt>\\fireball</tt>” into your local network area. This will open a prompt for the Fireball’s name and password.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360002229733/WinFindFireball.png" alt="WinFindFireball.png"></p>
<!-- -->
<p id="macNetwork" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;6.</strong> FOR MACINTOSH: Find the listing for Fireball on your local network in Finder.</p>
<p>If no such listing appears, add it manually. In finder, click “Go→ Connect to Server” and input ‘<tt>fireball</tt>’.</p>
<p><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360002229833/macFinderDlg.png" alt="macFinderDlg.png"></p>
<!-- -->
<p id="mountShare" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;7.</strong> Mount the share <em><tt>DataForB2</tt></em></p>
<p>Mount the share <em><tt>DataForB2</tt></em> and enter the username and password provided by Backblaze (<a href="#installSA">Please see the <em>Download and Install Synology Assistant</em> instructions</a>).</p>
<!-- -->
<p id="copyData" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>&nbsp;8.</strong> Copy the data to the Fireball NAS</p>
<p>Copy all the data to the Fireball. <strong>Please note there are some restrictions on files sent to B2 storage via Fireball.</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The folder or filepath <strong>must not</strong> contain any of the following characters:
<div class="table-container"><table class=" wysiwyg-text-align-center" style="margin: .5em auto .5em auto; height: 109px; width: 679px; font-weight: normal; font-size: larger; text-align: center;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>Character</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Name</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>ASCII</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>Unicode</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>*</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Asterisk</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>43</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+002A</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>:</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Colon</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>58</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+003A</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>?</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Question Mark</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>63</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+003F</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>\</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Backslash</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>92</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+005C</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>/</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Slash (Solidus)</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>47</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+002F</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>&lt;</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Less-than sign</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>60</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+002C</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>"</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Quotation Mark</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>34</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+0022</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>&gt;</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Greater-than sign</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>62</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+003E</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 128.5px;">
<p>|</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 250.5px;">
<p>Vertical Bar</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 121px;">
<p>124</p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 167px;">
<p>U+007C</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>
</li>
<li>The file name starts with any of the following:
<div class="table-container"><table style="margin: .5em auto .5em auto; font-size: larger;">
<tbody style="text-align: center; font-weight: normal;">
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p><em>Character Sequence</em></p>
</td>
<td>
<p><em> <!-- spacer --> </em></p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p><em>Description</em></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p><strong><tt>.~</tt></strong></p>
</td>
<td>
<p><em> <!-- spacer --> </em></p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p>Full stop followed by tilde (squiggle)</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p><strong><tt>._</tt></strong></p>
</td>
<td>
<p><em> <!-- spacer --> </em></p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p>Full stop followed by low line (underscore)</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p><strong><tt>~</tt></strong></p>
</td>
<td>
<p><em> <!-- spacer --> </em></p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p>Tilde (squiggle)</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</td>
<td>
<p><em> <!-- spacer --> </em></p>
</td>
<td style="text-align: center;">
<p>Reserved Synology filename</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>
</li>
<li>The file or folder name is or contains any of the following:<br>
<div class="table-container"><table style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 99.8487%; height: 698px;" data-mce-id="__mce" border="1">
<tbody>
<tr style="height: 22px;">
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;"><strong>Name</strong></td>
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;"><strong>Description</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 22px;">
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">.DS_Store<br>Icon\r</td>
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">macOS special files and folders</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 22px;">
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">desktop.ini<br>Desktop.ini<br>Thumbs.db</td>
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">Windows special files and folders</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 22px;">
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">
<p>.SynologyWorkingDirectory<br>#recycle<br>sharebin<br>SynologyCloudSync<br>cloudsync_encrypt.info<br>SynoEAStream<br>SynoResource</p>
<p>@eaDir</p>
<p>.synoppsdb</p>
</td>
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">Synology special files and folders</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 22px;">
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">
<p>.gdoc<br>.gsheet<br>.gdraw<br>.gslides<br><br></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</td>
<td style="width: 50%; height: 22px;">Google docs special files and folders</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>
</li>
<li>The folder or file path is longer than 1000 (one thousand) characters</li>
<li>The file name is longer than 143 (one hundred and forty three) characters</li>
<li>Folder names must not end with a period or full stop ( <tt>.</tt> )</li>
<li>The file is a symlink</li>
<li>macOS extended attributes like Finder metadata, and Resource Forks will not be synced to B2</li>
<li>Files that point to online resources may not upload as expected. For example, when Google Docs syncs a file to the desktop, the file created locally is not a working copy of the document but a symbolic link (symlink) to the cloud version. Copying this kind of file does not create a backup of the actual file, just a copy of the link.</li>
</ul>
<!-- -->
<p id="synShutDown" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>9.</strong> Return NAS settings to default, and shut down the NAS</p>
<p>If you have made any changes to the NAS device specific to your environment, such as network settings, set them back to the defaults. This makes uploading the data easier when Backblaze receives the unit. Shut down the NAS from the Synology web interface.</p>
<p style="margin: .5em auto .5em auto; text-align: center;"><img src="/hc/article_attachments/360002229813/nasShutdown.png" alt="NAS Shutdown Diagol"></p>
<!-- -->
<p id="repackDrives" style="margin: 2em 0em 0em 0em;"><strong>10. </strong>Uninstall the hard drives, repack and return the Fireball to Backblaze</p>
<p>To ensure the integrity of the NAS and the hard drives, uninstall the hard drives from the NAS trays, repack the drives and NAS, and send them back to Backblaze. Once received, Backblaze will connect the NAS to an internal network, and complete the file upload at network traffic speeds.</p>
<p>Return the Fireball unit to:</p>
<div style="margin: 0 0 0 05%; font-weight: bolder; font-size: 110%;">Backblaze Fireball Return<br>500 Ben Franklin Court<br>San Mateo, CA 94401</div>
<!-- --></div>
<!-- --></div>
<p>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;</p>
<div style="margin: 1em 0em 2em 0em;">
<div style="border: 5px; border-style: solid; border-color: 113c4a; padding: 10px; margin: 0 5% 0 5%; background-color: #dddddd;">
<h3 style="text-align: center; color: #3f7b70; font-variant: small-caps;"><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-x-large">For Integration Partners :</span></h3>
<ul>
<li><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-large" style="color: #265a5c;">To simplify and enable testing for our integration partners, Backblaze has configured a virtual Fireball in a VMWare image. <a href="https://f001.backblazeb2.com/file/fireballvm/FireballVM.xhtml">Instructions, including a link to the approximately 4GB image, are available here</a>.</span></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <a href="/hc/en-us/articles/360002004214-How-to-Upload-Files-to-B2-Using-Fireball" class="btn btn--primary promoted__body-btn">
                                    <span>Read more</span>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-right is-hidden--rtl"></i>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-left is-hidden--ltr"></i>
                                </a>
                            </div>
                        
                            <div id="promoted-1260802744330" class="tabs__container" aria-hidden="true">
                                <div class="promoted__body-container">
                                    <h2>Whistleblower Hotline</h2>
                                    <div data-article-body="" data-plugin-article-body="">
                                        <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you become aware of an actual or potential violation of laws, rules, regulations, or any of Backblaze policies, you can report this anonymously in one of two ways:</span></p>
<ol>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">By emailing to anonymous[at]Backblaze.com </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1">Report this online by filling in the <a style="background-color: #ffffff; font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;" href="https://forms.gle/ouDpWfDaUkenmVj47" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anonymous Reporting Form</a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></li>
</ol>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <a href="/hc/en-us/articles/1260802744330-Whistleblower-Hotline" class="btn btn--primary promoted__body-btn">
                                    <span>Read more</span>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-right is-hidden--rtl"></i>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-left is-hidden--ltr"></i>
                                </a>
                            </div>
                        
                            <div id="promoted-1260801741670" class="tabs__container" aria-hidden="true">
                                <div class="promoted__body-container">
                                    <h2>Report Phishing Content</h2>
                                    <div data-article-body="" data-plugin-article-body="">
                                        <p><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-large">If you suspect you have received a phishing email with content hosted on our servers, please send an email to reportphishing @ Backblaze . com.</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Please ensure to include who the email was sent from and the link that routes to our domain.</p>
<p><span class="wysiwyg-font-size-medium">The link should begin with "https://f000.backblazb2.com" or "https://f001.backblazeb2.com" or "https://f002.backblazeb2.com."</span></p>
                                    </div>
                                </div>
                                <a href="/hc/en-us/articles/1260801741670-Report-Phishing-Content" class="btn btn--primary promoted__body-btn">
                                    <span>Read more</span>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-right is-hidden--rtl"></i>
                                    <i class="fas fa-chevron-left is-hidden--ltr"></i>
                                </a>
                            </div>
                        
                    </div>

                </div>

            </div>
        </div>

    </section>




    <section id="activity" class="section section--padding activity activity--type-2">

esk.com/knowledge/content_tags?brand_id=201094","community_badges_url":"https://backblaze.zendesk.com/knowledge/community_badges?brand_id=201094","community_settings_url":"https://backblaze.zendesk.com/knowledge/community_settings?brand_id=201094","gather_plan_state":"subscribed","search_settings_url":"https://backblaze.zendesk.com/knowledge/search_settings?brand_id=201094","has_multibrand_search_in_plan":true,"has_search_settings_in_plan":true,"theming_api_version":2,"theming_settings":{"translations_enable":false,"logo":"//theme.zdassets.com/theme_assets/34506/2b079d3c8769eaa193b68496a4ac4b49b37449b0.svg","logo_light":"//theme.zdassets.com/theme_assets/34506/132cc94aba261b7f03a2ded0135a187d0430c14e.svg","logo_height":"40px","favicon":"//theme.zdassets.com/theme_assets/34506/38122f53f85d4786b798ce2dcab0480a736db518.png","primary_color":"rgba(226,
